The Generals shake their heads in admiration.  They clenc cigars, summoning up the Stuff for the ordeal that clearl ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Gordie's room, Horton-as-Wally pounds the final nail i last in a wallfull of professional looking gun racks.  Th are already loaded with Gordie's toy weapons.  Horton-as- to Gordie. HORTON-AS-WALLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Load 'er up. Gordie loads the rest of his toys into the rack. HORTON-AS-WALLY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many rounds in a Luger magazine? GORDIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nine, Sir. HORTON-AS-WALLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the range on that Kalishnikov? GORDIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Accurate to three-hundred yards, Sir. HORTON-AS-WALLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you ever point a loaded weapon  at another human being if you don't  intend to use it? GORDIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Sir, never, Sir. HORTON-AS-WALLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's good, Gordon.  Tomorrow we're going to talk about hand-to-hand  techniques.  Now go tell your Mother  we're ready to eat. GORDIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Sir, I sure am hungry. HORTON-AS-WALLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and me both, Junior. Gordie exits happily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Horton-as-Wally enters, Polly, wearing a blond, plasti brace, ios setting out large amounts of food on the table Gordie's eagerly seated, his head bobbing. POLLY (her voice strangely Munchkined)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wally, I don't appreciate one little  bit being told by Gordie that you're  ready to -- Horton-as-Wally sits down, calmly takes out his Magnum an on the table beside his plate.  Polly inhales her next wo immediately sits.  Gordie stares directly at Horton-as-Wa trance of admiration. HORTON-AS-WALLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dig in, Gordon.  You'll need plenty  of energy when we go hand-to-hand. Polly's impulse to interrogate is just barely contained b terror.  Gordie starts to eat, still gazing worshipfully as-Wally. POLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wally, you'll remember we're having  the wine and cheese get-together  tomorrow evening and I'll need you to  pick -- (he shoots her a look)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- to remind me to pick up the wine  and cheese in the morning. HORTON-AS-WALLY (nods, then to Gordie)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we had some cheese, we could have a  wine and cheese party, if we had some wine. Gordie cracks up.  He loves his dad so much now. HORTON-AS-WALLY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Son, you're bobbing like a boy who needs a pogo stick.  What do you say  we pick one up tomorrow? GORDIE (thrilled)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gee, Dad, that'd be great -- what's  a pogo stick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A basketball court sized room, the ceilings almost out of The walls are covered with murals of animals and fantasy gigantic, electric rocking horse sits in the middle of th near a desk where Tidman is emptying the contents of a la sock in front of the seated Professor-as-Newt.  Ike and M standing guard nearby.  The Professor-as-Newt stares at t analytically, on the assumption they hold some hidden, sy significance. TIDMAN (puzzled)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you recognize these items,  Master Newt? The Professor-as-Newt looks at Tidman, as if to say, "Sho TIDMAN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are the contents of your sock. THE PROFESSOR-AS-NEWT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My sock. TIDMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right -- (picking each object up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is your rock.  This is your  piece of string.  This is your  pink rubber pig.  This is your  record player and your very  own record.  See? Tidman puts the plastic record on the plastic, toy turnta turns it on; a frantic, emotional children's SONG plays. this is all a test of his brilliance, the Professor-as-Ne his head like the RCA dog, listening intently.  He picks rock, scrutinizing it, measuring it with his fingers. THE PROFESSOR-AS-NEWT (shrewdly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Instantly I see a relationship to  ze string. TIDMAN (humoring him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  They were all in the sock. THE PROFESSOR-AS-NEWT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All in ze sock? TIDMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All ... in .... the sock. THE PROFESSOR-AS-NEWT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, a frame of reference. (putting it all together)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sock ... is my universe.  I'm going  to need a large chalkboard. TIDMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Master Newt, you've come a long, long way. THE PROFESSOR-AS-NEWT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Halfway around the world. TIDMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  Of course

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the curtain opens on the small stage, BLACK MUSICIANS an introductory, three-chord blues riff.  Jimmie Underwoo cronies are seated over drinks in their booth at the back comes out on stage and takes the microphone. VINNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, it gives me  great pleasure to introduce one  of the great legends of the blues,  it's his first visit here to the  Lightning Rod, direct from Gainesville,  Florida, the one and only Stompin'  Machine, Sammy "the Stomp" Johnson! Round of applause, whistles.  Jimmie and his group stomp and yell, heads bobbing in unison: the stomping spreads a room.  The musicians start to stomp, the beat is picked u amplified by the bass drum. A spotlight hits the stage an stomps Alice-as-Sammy-the-Stomp, wearing a baggy, blue-se suit, a purple pearlescent silk shirt, white bucks and a string tie.  The audience immediately accepts her at face the applause-o-meter shoots into the danger zone. Alice-as-Sammy-the-Stomp, sounding like a bizarro mixture King and Princess Di, skillfully sings a blues standard w deal of conviction, passion and diction. Through the beaded curtain at the back, Wally-as-Horton e Rod, scans the room, spots Jimmie and company and makes h their booth. GANGSTER #3

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Horton, where's Lorraine? WALLY-AS-HORTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lorraine? Jimmie backhands Gangster #3 across the nose. JIMMIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell business is it of yours where she is? (to Wally-as-Horton)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guy's got a deathwish, huh Horton? You gotta forgive a knothead like  this. The Gangsters scrunch together to make room for Wally-as- join them in the booth.  They watch Alice-as-Sammy-the-St her number.  Applause. Under which, Lorraine teeters in on stiletto heels, dress clinging, cocktail sheath dress, with a slit up the side Duluth.  She leans down and gives Wally-as-Horton a big w LORRAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry I'm late. Wally-as-Horton's eyes roll back, close to losing conscio LORRAINE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doin' sittin' with  these creeps? WALLY-AS-HORTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're going to give me a drink. LORRAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean a Mickey. JIMMY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lighten up, Lorraine, you gonna stop a man from buying a man a drink in this  oh-by-gosh-by-golly world? LORRAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who me? (she sits) JIMMY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're not gonna stop me ... (Jimmy winks at the others)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... then I'm not gonna stop you.  I can't stop you.  And if I can't stop you, then -- THE OTHER GANGSTERS (stupid singing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- "who'll stop Lorraine?" On stage, Alice-as-Sammy-the-Stomp overhears the gangster interpreting it as a request, launches the band into a ti explosive cover of CCR's "Who'll Stop the Rain?" Jimmy raises his wine glass. JIMMY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to propose a toast ... Wally-as-Horton, Lorraine and the other Gangsters raise t glasses. JIMMY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To Mr. Horton Thuraby, the fastest  gun in the west, with all good wishes  for continued success, especially in  whatever it is you might be doing at  the present time, which we have not  been let in on but tomorrow's a new  day ... They wait to see if he's finished.  Wally-as-Horton leans forward, forms a perfect "O" with his lips, attaches his glass and makes like the babbling brook.  The others look like he just flew in from Mars.  He continues to make the The Gangsters and Lorraine look at each other.  Cautiousl lean forward and duplicate Wally-as-Horton's wine tasting The band stops playing, all eyes turn to the booth.  The the babbling brook continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Busier than before.  A few happy SKATERS are seated at th counter, heads all bobbing.  Holding a sheet of hamburger an accordion, Randy leans in uncomfortable close to one S RANDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was telling Big Tom I smell gas. And I still smell gas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stripping receipts off the spindle nearby, Woody grimaces on his hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lorraine and Wally-as-Horton make their way up the stairs as-Horton is half in the bag, leading them in singing a m version of "Strangers in the Night".  They stop outside t Horton's apartment.  Wally-as-Horton extends a hand. WALLY-AS-HORTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, this is where I get off. LORRAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and me both, you animal. WALLY-AS-HORTON (shaking her hand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for a wonderful evening,  Laura. LORRAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You clown -- oh, I see, you want  to play Perfect Strangers, I like  this. (she grabs his necktie)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you take me into your  apartment, Harley and let's see if I can  get that big engine of your's started? We HEAR a rapid thumping, increasing in volume and intens Wally-as-Horton's shirt starts to kick out like he's hidi mule undergoing shock treatment in his chest. She opens the door and pulls him by the tie into the dark The door closes.  From inside, we hear Wally-as-Horton's beating faster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The early morning sun illuminates the "Welcome to Newtonv Parked behind the sign in his patrol car, Dougy "Sherlock catching some Z's.  His head bobs slightly in his sleep. In the distance we hear the grinding and screeching of th A" limo as it tears down the highway and roars past the s "Sherlock" Watson wakes up like someone just poured ice w shorts and sees the limo racing away.  He starts the engi the siren and screeches out onto the highway, bubble ligh flashing, chasing the limo. CAMERA holds on the sign.  A few moments later, the patro back past the sign in reverse, the limo gaining on his fr "Sherlock" Watson testing the envelope of landspeed-backw travel. The wretched whine of tortured engines fades.  Lightning desert in background.  Moments later, what seems to be a erupts in the dry desert around the sign.  Descending int malstrom, we see a contorted, white apparition attached t harness on a cable; General Conrad, in a new plaster body As he nears the ground, two troop carriers and a jeep spe frame, combat-ready GROUND TROOPS pour out and lower Gene into a steel-tube scaffolding that allows him to stand in of the jeep.  He's strapped in, a microphone in front of and large speakers on either side of him. During above, the Generals with the Right Stuff and Colon arrive in a fleet of staff cars and three more transports three companies of Marines. GENERAL CONRAD (into the loudspeakers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fall out! Fall out!  Secure the perimeter  of Newtonville!  No one gets in or out  without my say-so!  Move, move, move!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Songbirds.  Peace.  No one in sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An empty corridor.  A blaring alarm starts filling the co sound.  We hear frantic, running footsteps approaching an later a panicked HEINZ EMPLOYEE comes into view around a screaming ... HEINZ EMPLOYEE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carrying his sock and the Trick Dog, Newt-as-the-Professo escorted into a small, sparsely appointed laboratory by B Mel.  In the room are a chalkboard, a box of chalk, a cha periodic table of elements hanging on a wall. BERT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are all the things you asked  for, Professor. NEWT-AS-THE PROFESSOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four MEL (nose expertly bandaged)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For your work.  You're sure there's  nothing else you need? NEWT-AS-THE PROFESSOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zero. BERT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Professor. MEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going now. BERT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll leave you to it. No response.  Bert and Mel exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bert and Mel stop in the corridor. BERT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He seems pretty preoccupied. MEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure he's got a lot on his mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Newt-as-the Professor looks at the closed door. NEWT-AS-THE PROFESSOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One.  Two.  Three.  Four.  Five. Newt-as-the Professor sits on the floor and opens his soc Trick Dog sits beside him, watching attentively. NEWT-AS-THE PROFESSOR (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zero. He takes his piece of string out of his sock and lays it floor. NEWT-AS-THE PROFESSOR (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One. He takes his smooth rock out of the sock and sets it down exact distance from the string. NEWT-AS-THE PROFESSOR (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two. We move off him towards a large mirror in the wall to his

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a room filled with whirring computers, the group of Co SCIENTISTS we saw earlier observe Newt-as-the Professor t one-way glass mirror.  Some of them sit at computer conso to input Newt-as-the Professor's every action into their hard discs.  Mel and Bert enter and stand at the back of near Sammy-"the Stomp"-as Alice. BERT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is what we've been waiting for. MEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To watch an authentic genius at work. One of the Scientists shushes them.  The group watches as the Professor takes his plastic record player out of the carefully sets it down.  Video cameras record his every m NEWT-AS-THE PROFESSOR (through a speaker in Room A)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three. They watch as Newt-as-the Professor takes out his record on the turntable. NEWT-AS-THE PROFESSOR (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four. Newt-as-the Professor turns it on; we hear the same frant children's song we heard on the other record player at Ne The Scientists look at each other, a little wide-eyed. SCIENTIST #1 (reassuringly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like he's getting warmed up. SCIENTIST #2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's priming the pump. SAMMY-THE-STOMP-AS-ALICE (aside to Bert and Mel)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is one peculiar pump. Bert and Mel look him/her up and down. Newt-as-the Professor takes the pink, rubber pig out of t sets it down near the other objects. NEWT-AS-THE PROFESSOR (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five. Newt-as-the Professor opens the box of chalk, takes out a chalk and feeds it into the open hold in the pig's mouth. up and starts flying the pig around the room in time to t He occasionally grazes the chalk that extends out of the against the blackboard.  The Trick Dog starts jumping bac forth over the chair. NEWT-AS-THE PROFESSOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Candy Pigs.  Candy Pigs. SCIENTIST #1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd heard his methods were unorthodox. SCIENTIST #2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stand by on computers; we'll have to  be on our toes ... school is in session. The other Scientists nod in uncertain agreement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Newt-as-the Professor cruises around the room with the pi passes the periodic table on the far wall, we notice an e watching Newt-as-the Professor through the letter "o" in "oxygen".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The eyeball belongs to Mr. Posthole, the Company "B" spy, away in this tiny, dark space.  He speaks into a small tr hidden in his pen holder. MR. POSTHOLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now he's simulating a kinetic flow  with the porcine symbol ... my  guess is he's establishing a spatial  vector between the objects for the  purpose of conceptual comparisons ... (overwhelmed by the "brilliance")

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... my God, I can't believe what I'm  witnessing, tell Mr. Biggs he's shed  more light on Arbitrary Permutation in  the last three minutes than we got in  two years out in the bush observing  the Mystic Sufis -- (back to business)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I kidding myself, or does the dog  represent Heisenberg's Uncertainty  Principle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beautiful summer morning.  Horton-as-Wally drives up, p the sales office and heads inside.  He feels like whistli out a note before catching himself.  He enters the sales

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Horton-as-Wally enters, Lucky Buck gestures to him fro his desk. LUCKY BUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soldier, First Bugle's at 0900  hours, I'd like you to take a good  long look at your timepiece, bedbug,  and give me one good reason why I  shouldn't dock you three minutes  wages.  You're a slacker, a slouch; the original sadsack. Horton-as-Wally, motionless, stares at this creature in d A twinge of uneasiness filters down to Lucky Buck's corte shakes it off, crooks a finger and summons Horton-as-Wall LUCKY BUCK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walk that butt of yours right over here. Private, I want to show you what put me  off my breakfast this morning. Horton-as-Wally, stoking a nuclear powered slow burn, amb the desk, under ... LUCKY BUCK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The most pitiful, the most sickening  and embarrassing sales record it's  ever been my misfortune to encounter. We're talking court martial.  Dishonorable  discharge. HORTON-AS-WALLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you say? LUCKY BUCK (on micro-thin ice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said if this was Japan and I were  to hand you the hari-kari blade and  you were anything but the most miserable  excuse for a man in this outfit -- HORTON-AS-WALLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's enough. Horton-as-Wally reaches out, grips Lucky Buck by the Adam puts him gently against the wall and speaks calmly. HORTON-AS-WALLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The things you've been saying and  this attitude you're expressing  towards me are unacceptable.  You  will never do this again. LUCKY BUCK (up about two octaves)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I agree completely. HORTON-AS-WALLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.  Let's sell some cars. LUCKY BUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm all for it. Horton-as-Wally releases Lucky Buck.  Lucky Buck tells hi uncooperative facial muscles to smile, but the result loo mouth of a catfish in a wind tunnel. LUCKY BUCK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tidman enters, with Ike and Mike behind him.  The Profess sits at his desk, contemplating the contents of the sock carefully out on the desktop, deeply lost in thought.  A blank blackboard stands at the ready. TIDMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Master Newt. No response.  The Professor-as-Newt doesn't budge, doesn' TIDMAN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sleep well, did you?  Master  Newt?  Master Newt? Tidman touches the Professor-as-Newt's shoulder.  The Pro Newt snaps out of his reverie and looks up at Tidman. THE PROFESSOR-AS-NEWT (instantly alert)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vhat kind of day is it?  Is it a  cloudy day?  Or is it a pleasant day? TIDMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a pleasant day, Master Newt. THE PROFESSOR-AS-NEWT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's good. (they smile at each other)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the fellow who was in here before. TIDMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I'm Tidman. THE PROFESSOR-AS-NEWT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tidman.  You'll understand if I  return to my work now. He turns back to the desktop.  Tidman looks at Ike and Mi TIDMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Master Newt ... it's time for your  morning bath. THE PROFESSOR-AS-NEWT (getting aggravated)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, kind sir, can't you see ...  I am this close -- (holds up thumb and forefinger)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- this close -- these symbols are  swimming, swarming in my mind like  your bumblebees I've heard so much  about -- what pulls and pushes is  looking more and more like the  interwoven fibers of the SOCK!! TIDMAN (a pause, sternly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you see your pig? THE PROFESSOR-AS-NEWT (thinking it's a clue, excited)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes? TIDMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're just as dirty as a pig. THE PROFESSOR-AS-NEWT (eager to know more)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am?  What does this mean? TIDMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's time to see your Grandfather ... it's time for your bath. THE PROFESSOR-AS-NEWT (a new tangent)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dirt ... water ... like a MEMBRANE!! Tidman motions to Ike and Mike.  They pick the Professor- by the arms and carry him towards the door. TIDMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Master Newt? They stop.  The Professor-as-Newt looks back at him. TIDMAN (CONT'D) (holding it up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you want to bring your pig? THE PROFESSOR-AS-NEWT (considers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vell, yes.  I suppose I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ike and Mike carry the Professor-as-Newt, who's cradling into the Roman bath-sized room.  Tidman follows.  Ike and regular bathing suits and t-shirts.  The Professor-as-New wearing a 1890's style bathing suit.  Also wearing the sa suit, GRANDAD NEWTON, an ancient, shriveled version of Ne unsteadily in the far end of the steamy, swimming pool si bathtub.  On the back of both their suits are the words:

dialogues.speaker: LONG DISTANCE SWIMMER
dialogues.text: Ike and Mike carry the Professor-as-Newt down steps into and drop him kitty-korner from Grandad.  Tidman announces TIDMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grandad, Master Newt is here. Grandad looks at the Professor-as-Newt, shakes his head. GRANDAD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not Newt. TIDMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be mean, Grandad, Newt's come such  a long way to see you.  And I'll bet he'd  love to hear your record; wouldn't you  like to play it for him? THE PROFESSOR-AS-NEWT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I vould like to hear your record.  Does it  have any bearing on the pig?  Or perhaps,  dirt or a membrane of some kind? Grandad smiles warmly; he likes this guy even if it isn't he's the only one who realizes it.  Grandad reaches out o and turns on his plastic record player, similar to the on sock. We hear a sweet, tender, warm-hearted song.  As it Grandad takes out his own pink rubber pig and starts to s with a little brush.  The Professor-as-Newt watches him i smiling when Grandad smiles at him.  GRANDAD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clean pig. THE PROFESSOR-AS-NEWT (aha, another clue)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A...clean...pig. The Professor-as-Newt starts to scrub his pig.  Using lon handled brushes, Ike and Mike begin scrubbing down Granda the Professor-as-Newt.  Tidman steals behind a column and a smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moving off a clock that reads 12:33, we see Hank the Barb exit the Barber Shop and move to the newsstand.  He picks a newspaper and hands it to the Cashier. CASHIER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hank, usual? HANK THE BARBER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bet you. The Cashier takes the paper, opens the cash register draw and tries to stuff the newspaper inside.  Meanwhile, Hank a candy bar and smears it in a tight circle on his forehe near the third eye area.  The Cashier takes out a handful nickels and dimes, holds out his arm and throws the coins the corridor floor.  The Barber and the Cashier stare at other with a look of complete blankness.  The Barber spin violently and storms back to the Barbershop. Moving off them we find General Conrad, Colonel Mofler an other Generals observing the exchange.  A SOLDIER approac urgently. SOLDIER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General, if you'd like to follow me. GENERAL CONRAD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it? SOLDIER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we've got a nibble. They quickly follow the Soldier, Mofler and the other Gen carrying General Conrad to the baggage claim area.  The c been roped off and a number of SOLDIERS are crawling arou carrying weird, Geiger-counter-like devices, all glowing emitting whooping noises. GENERAL CONRAD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You smell that, Mofler?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLONEL MOFLER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that, Sir? GENERAL CONRAD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tuna piss. COLONEL MOFLER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Sir.  Ground Zero. GENERAL CONRAD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mofler, you know what happens when tuna  goes bad? Mofler nods, apprehensive, as the other Generals gather r GENERAL CONRAD (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentleman, we've got twenty-four hours to  cook this fish before it starts drawing  flies from Washington.  I don't have to tell  you who'll have his barnacles scraped in  drydock if that happens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sales office is teeming with a crowd of anxious, head CAR PURCHASERS.  Lucky Buck, in seventh heaven behind his processing purchase agreements as fast as he can write. LUCKY BUCK (over above, voice still high)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take a number, please ... Lucky  Buck'll get to you lucky shoppers  as soon as he can ... CAR PURCHASERS  (variously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got to have that car ... Wally  said it was the car for me and I  think he was right! ... I love that  car ... Wally wants me to have this  car and I don't want to upset him,  he was quite insistent ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Horton-as-Wally walks a slow, rheumatic LITTLE OLD LADY f the elbow through the lot.  As her head bobs, her eye is flashy, sporty convertible. LITTLE OLD LADY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'm really kind of partial  to that one -- HORTON-AS-WALLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. He stops her in front of a sensible, four-door sedan. HORTON-AS-WALLY (CONT'D) (finger in her face)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the car for you. They Lady's eye's quiver.  We hear a splashing on the tar a puddle forming between her orthopedic shoes. LITTLE OLD LADY (not eager to disappoint him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do I sign?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmie Underwood and the Boys sit around a table, over be bobbing, deeply troubled. JIMMIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can you tail a guy who don't  go out of his room? MEXICAN GANGSTER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are they doing up there? They all punch him on the shoulders. MEXICAN GANGSTERS (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I mean, this ain't like Horton; he don't mix business with pleasure. JIMMIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Horton's beginning to act like an  enigma. The other Gangsters brush off their sleeves and pick lint lapels.  Mr. Biggs and his two Bodyguards are eavesdroppi conversation from the next booth.  Mr. Biggs gets up and Jimmie Underwood. MR. BIGGS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't help overhearing what you gentlemen were discussing.  I, too,  have concern with regards to the behavior  of Mr. Horton Thursby.  Perhaps we can  find a path through this thicket of  doubt and confusion to a golden pagoda  of mutual satisfaction. JIMMIE UNDERWOOD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're Mr. Biggs. MR. BIGGS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed I am, Sir.  Let's talk turkey. MEXICAN GANGSTER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Con mucho queso. JIMMIE UNDERWOOD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There isn't gonna be any turkey or cheese.  Your deal's with Thursby. MR. BIGGS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Until this moment.  I consider it  void for non-performance of services. Take Thursby out ... and the deal is  yours. JIMMIE UNDERWOOD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One, two, three ... The gangsters all give the thumbs up sign on the silent c "four"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A clock reads:  2:00 PM.  Wearing a smile as wide as the  Mississippi, Wally-as-Horton lounges between the sheets w Lorraine.  Wally-as-Horton sings her a little ditty.  She like an adored and adorable schoolgirl. WALLY-AS-HORTON (picture Gary Cooper, happy drunk)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gosh, I think you're peachy/ And I'll bet you'd look real swell/ In a swimsuit at the beachy/ You really ring my bell/ Gosh, of gosh, oh gosh. He pinches her nose, then holds up the tip of his thumb b fingers.  WALLY-AS-HORTON (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I keep this, will it start to smell? She giggles.  He kisses her "nose" and puts it "back". LORRAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Horton, this is the most romantic  day we've ever spent. WALLY-AS-HORTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh gosh. LORRAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I feel anymore love I think I'll just  wiggle right out of my skin!! WALLY-AS-HORTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awww.  Me too. She kisses him tenderly and quickly accelerating passion. Horton's t-shirt starts thumping like a jackhammer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A number of dairy cows stand in the field, moving their l making an eerie, melodic yodeling.  Moving over we find G Conrad, Colonel Mofler and the Generals standing on the e field.  Behind them, a mass of Soldiers are standing by. Generals looks through a huge pair of binoculars.  Colone holds a tape recorder's microphone towards the cows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on a big pair of yodeling cow's lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Newt-as-the-Professor lays out the piece of string on the picks up the rock and bangs it up in down on the string i the song on the record player.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Newt-as-the Professor on a video monitor mounted o Company "A"'s secret boardroom.  Cinderblock walls, low g fluorescent lights.  The group of Scientists we saw earli observing Newt-as-the Professor are seated around the tab watching the monitor with Chairman Delbert Corrigan and h wife, Simone.  Bert and Mel are standing quietly in the b Sammy "the Stomp"-as-Alice.  Everyone watches the monitor heads bobbing, as we hear the tap-tap-tapping of Newt-as- Professor's rock.  A plate of small sandwiches sits in th the table. DELBERT CORRIGAN (watching the monitor, dumbfounded)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Interesting.  But, somehow, vague. SIMONE (cutting the bullshit)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell is he  doing?  We paid  top dollar for this dimwit. SCIENTIST #1 (cowed but unbroken)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Corrigan, please, this is an intuitive,  rhythmic translation of pure thought  into interpretive kineseology. SIMONE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh please. SCIENTIST #2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We think it's a code.  We just haven't  cracked it yet. SIMONE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you what's cracked around here,  he is.  He was cracked when he got here. DELBERT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps he was damaged in shipping. At the back, Bert and Mel exchange an anxious glance.  Me and draws a finger across his throat. BERT (nods, whispers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pink slips, Mel. MEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time to update those resumes. SCIENTIST #1 (showing scads of print-outs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our data indicates he's in the process  of establishing the formula. Still in time to the music, Newt-as-the-Professor is now pig with the rock and jumping it down on the string.  Eac hits it, the pig emits a high, sharp squeak. DELBERT CORRIGAN (trying to grasp it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, the frustration of the layman. SCIENTIST #2 (trying to be helpful)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Might I suggest you read Smyth on the  encoding of natural processes in syncopated  Pygmy drumbeats? Simone lets out a heavy, critical sigh and rolls her eyes DELBERT CORRIGAN (trying to sum up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think what Simone and I are trying  to say, old boys, is that we're  somewhat concerned, as anyone would  be after a cash outlay of this magnitude,  with no apparent return other than these  inscrutable, albeit intriguing abstractions. (loses his train of thought)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Company "A" is behind you one hundred  percent. (bites into a sandwich)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cracking good sandwiches, these.  Sandwich,  Simone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MONTAGE: whirring computers; on computer monitors, black stills of the lab floor are overlaid with a grid, compute vectors compute distances between the objects with calipe feeding the data over microphone to programmers at keyboa Scientist with headphones on analyzes the music from Newt on computer. In the secret observation room behind the element chart, Posthole video tapes Newt-as-the-Professor through the pe In another computer room at company "B", the video data f Posthole's camera is on a big monitor, being analyzed by "B"'s battery of computers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sign reads:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Horton-as-Wally leads Gordie stand in front of the counte kindly old MISTER ZAP climbs up a tall ladder, pulls a po down off a shelf and blows off a thick layer of dust. MISTER ZAP (still on the ladder)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep.  Haven't sold one of these things  in years.  Got a back order died on  the shelf.  Been clogging up my  inventory since '59.  Used to be I'd  see kids bouncing all over Main  Street on these things. (getting carried away)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wished I had a nickel for every one  of these I saw bouncing by my window. Could'a sold this old shop.  Could'a  moved up ta Granny's farm 'fore the  rheumatism took her.  Yep, I -- HORTON-AS-WALLY (no good can come from this)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's enough. At 8 fps, Mr. Zap zips down the ladder and rings up the s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Regular speed.  Horton-as-Wally watches with a smile as G on the stick and bounces away down Main Street.  A couple bobbing KIDS spot Gordie and are thunderstruck with desir stick of their own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sun set over the big skate.  The exterior lights come on. parking lot is jammed with cars and would-be skaters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In front of the empty skate dispensing shelves, Big Tom, Randy stare in amazement at the rink, packed solid, shoul shoulder with happy skaters, a mass of human flesh travel and around. WOODY (incredulous)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is great business, even for a Friday. BIG TOM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pinch me, Woody, I think we're dreaming. WOODY (has to worry about something)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are these people?  They look like  total strangers. RANDY (at his most insistent)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big Tom.  I still smell -- Woody clamps a hand over Randy's mouth. BIG TOM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, the sound of many skates on wood. CLOSE-UPS of many skates thunderously wheeling around the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Horton-as-Wally scrutinizes pairs of polyester-clad GUEST the house for the wine and cheese party, each carrying a wine.  Polly greets them at the door and they all pointed Horton-as-Wally. GUESTS AND POLLY (variously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were so fortunate to find this last  dusty little bottle ... Ted's so silly  he thought Neuf de Pape was the sound  champagne made when you opened it ... we thought you'd like this adorable  burgundy ... I've read about it; it's  ingratiating without being impudent ... Polly glances over at Horton-as-Wally.  He's just turned on his slow burn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thunderous applause from the packed house, among them som watching strategically. A spot comes up on Mayor Billy Be walks out on stage.  Watching from a gold circle box on t level are General Conrad, Colonel Mofler and the other Ge MAYOR BILLY BENSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, thank you and welcome, one  and all. (his hand is bobbing erratically)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before I introduce the illustrious Chinese Acrobats I have an important announcement  to make. (the crowd hushes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During the last twenty-four hours I, Mayor  Billy Benson, have struggled mightily with  the questions and issues weighing heavily  on all our minds in these, our troubled times. Ladies and gentlemen, Atlas did not shrug. GENERAL CONRAD (whispers to Mofler)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's my bozo gun? MAYOR BILLY BENSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And so it is tonight, with a heart filled with  joy and promise, that I am announcing my  candidacy for the office of President of these  United States of America. Dead silence.  Benson twitches, salutes sharply and strid GENERAL CONRAD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drop a net on that one, Mofler. COLONEL MOFLER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got trout farm written all over him. The band strikes up the Chinese overture.  Lights dim.  C open.  To tumultuous applause the thirty-five Texans stri take a bow. GENERAL CONRAD (squinting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kind'a big for Chinese. COLONEL MOFLER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe the stage is small. A steady drum bead-roll, the Texans scramble back and, pa straining, begin to form a massive, five-tiered human pyr Roger, the stage manager, watches from the wings, crossin fingers and biting a nail, as his head bobs. The men of the last tier climb precariously up to complet clumsiest and least graceful human pyramid in recorded hi bottom tier starts to shake and shimmy; the keystone Man' start to buckle.  The tiers sag inwards towards the middl look of eye-popping strain, the keystone Man farts.  A sp later, another first-tier Texan rips a cheese-cutter and collapses like a dynamited housing project. ROGER (averting his eyes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chinese food.  Ix-nay on the Chinese food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wally-as-Horton and Lorraine come down the stairs, happil each other.  They enter the main room of the Rod.  CUSTOM wolfing down huge portions of Vinnie's bad food.  Jimmie Gangsters, seated at a table in the middle of the room, a apprehensive, on edge.  Vinnie approaches. VINNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evening, Horton. WALLY-AS-HORTON (happily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evening.  We're starved! LORRAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For food, that is, but not for anything  else. VINNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two deluxe dinners, coming right up. (he moves off) JIMMIE (strained)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a seat with us, Horton.  We've got  plenty of room. WALLY-AS-HORTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gee, thanks, Mr. Underwood. The other Gangsters back away from the table, as Wally-as Lorraine take a seat.  Vinnie sets down two sticky plates undifferentiated sludge. VINNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buon appetito! (he moves off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other Gangsters sit down again.  Wally-as-Horton feel tension and starts to get nervous.  Jimmie Underwood move Wally-as-Horton into the shadows.  High violin/rash music as Wally-as-Horton's rash starts to bedevil him.  He move are uncomfortably as he starts to eat. LORRAINE (picking up on the danger)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Horton, something's not right. WALLY-AS-HORTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, this food is terrible. LORRAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  Where's Jimmie? Behind them, in the shadows, Jimmie Underwood slowly draw from his jacket.  His itch intensifying, Wally-as-Horton into his jacket to scratch his rash.  The Other Gangsters back, expecting the worse.  As Wally-as-Horton scratches accidently discharges the Magnum in his shoulder holster. The bullet shoots a hole in Wally-as-Horton's jacket, ric the metal chairleg, flies up and knocks the gun out of Ji Underwood's hand.  Wally-as-Horton spins around.  The oth Gangsters dive under the table and the rest of the room t WALLY-AS-HORTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh geez, Mr. Underwood, I'm so sorry,  are you okay? JIMMIE UNDERWOOD (reduced to a whimpering mass)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead, finish me. WALLY-AS-HORTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was you dinner that bad, too?  I could  cook better than that.  In fact I could  cook a lot better than that. LORRAINE (puzzled)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You cook? Silence.  The other Gangsters stare at him in bewildermen WALLY-AS-HORTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well ... yeah, I cook. JIMMIE UNDERWOOD (frantically looking for a foothold)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You cook?   cook, too. ITALIAN GANGSTER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You guys cook?  So do I. BLACK GANGSTER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No kidding?  I love to cook. MEXICAN GANGSTER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yo, tambien.  Con mucho queso!! JIMMIE UNDERWOOD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was always kind's afraid to say so. WALLY-AS-HORTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, there's nothing wrong with cooking. LORRAINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some of the world's greatest cooks are  men.  Maybe Vinnie will let you boys  cook something. CUSTOMERS (variously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything'd be better than this slop ... let 'em cook ... hey, Vinnie, let 'em  cook! (stomping as they shout)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let them cook!  Let them cook!  Let  them cook! VINNIE (happily joining in the chant)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They can cook!  They can cook! JIMMIE UNDERWOOD (offering a hand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whadda ya say, Hort? WALLY-AS-HORTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's cook!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The entire room full of Guests, and Polly, are doing the brook".  Horton-as-Wally watches them in disgusted disbel Guest with thick glasses turns to Horton-as-Wally. THICK-GLASSES GUEST

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're very quiet this evening, Wally. HORTON-AS-WALLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes I am. DICK, a big, mean Sportsman, has heard this exchange. DICK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose it's a little past your  bedtime, huh Wally? HORTON-AS-WALLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  I just want ot make sure Polly  enjoys her party. Within earshot, Polly smiles, enormously pleased, then st offering a tray full of turgid treats around the room.  POLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheese substitute?  Cheese substitute? A Second Sportsman Guest, HAL, slightly looped and smelli fun, moves next to Dick, near Horton-as-Wally. HAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dick and I were wondering if you'd sold your first car yet, Wally. DICK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, how long you been working there,  'bout fifteen years now, isn't it? You're headed for the Guiness Book  of World Records there, Wally boy. A moment of tense silence. POLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dick, I'll have you know Wally's sold  almost every car on the lot in the last  two days. HAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a sucker born every minute and  even a sucker can get a driver's license. POLLY (a bit aglow: can it be love?)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm very proud of Wally.  Lucky  Buck's make him a full partner. DICK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess Lucky Buck threw himself on  too many grenades. POLLY (sees the bumblebees in Horton's eyes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dick?  Are you trying to provoke Wally? DICK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Full partner?   Selling cars?  Is Polly  weaning you, Wally boy? HORTON-AS-WALLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me? DICK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thought for sure there'd be a little  rubber nipple on your glass there tonight.  You know; per usual. A buzzing like twelve cubic yards of killer bees fills th row of nervous female GUESTS "babble brook" their wine. HORTON-AS-WALLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you say? DICK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You heard me, Wimpy -- Horton-as-Wally throws a six-inch uppercut that puts Dick block down on "Queer Street".  Hal moves three centimeter Horton-as-Wally and one punch later finds himself on the looking for his eye-teeth. In one fluid motion Horton-as-Wally whips out the Magnum single shot down the row of female Guests, severing the s their wine glasses.  The wine empties onto the carpet lik through an hour glass. HORTON-AS-WALLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodnight. At 8 fps the room empties out the front door.  Returning speed, Horton-as-Wally holsters the Magnum.  Polly points entirely-angry finger at him. POLLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wally Newton! HORTON-AS-WALLY (responding in kind)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Polly Newton! He grabs her, spanks her once playfully.  She spanks him giggles.  He throws her over his shoulder and marches her to you-know-where.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little Gordie sleeps peacefully, a blissful smile on his cradles his precious pogo stick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wally-as-Horton and Jimmie Underwood are the boys are all laboring over different pots and griddles, each eagerly p his own specialty, moving in and around each other with p choreography, taste-testing, pondering, adjusting ingredi Lorraine is working as Wally-as-Horton's spice gofer. Vinnie comes back into the kitchen, carrying a huge stain baking tin.  VINNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This one big enough, Horton? WALLY-AS-HORTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That should do it, what do you think boys? The others nod and continue cooking.  Vinnie stands aroun fifth wheel. VINNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, how's it coming along? WALLY-AS-HORTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vinnie, Vinnie don't bug us.  We're  working on something that's never been  done before, ever. (to Lorraine)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lorraine, a dash of cardomon seed. (Lorraine complies) VINNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds expensive. WALLY-AS-HORTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes it is.  We're not gonna lie to  you, Vinnie, but we pull this off  and the Michelin people are gonna  need an extra star to rate this joint. VINNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gee, that's great.  Kind of a Meals  on Wheels sort of situation, what  with the tires and the food and all. Wally-as-Horton and Jimmie Underwood look at each other. WALLY-AS-HORTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not the tire company, Vinnie, this Michelin  is a snob outfit that rates swanky restaurants  and when we're finished you're goin' right to  the top of the list. VINNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. WALLY-AS-HORTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now if you can't stand the heat get out of  the kitchen, Vinnie. VINNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boys, you ever see a man my age do something  like this? He reaches up, grabs the pot rack and does a one-arm chin stare at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stage is littered with broken crockery.  A leisure-su socks pulled over his pants to his knees, holds two plate the air. General Conrad, Colonel Mofler and the Generals, some of dozing, stare on from their box, drifting into a surreali Drum roll.  A fat Texan swings in from the wings, hanging trapeze by his knees.  He makes a grab for the plates, mi good fifteen feet before swinging out of view on the othe the stage.  We hear a faint BARKING from that direction. on the trapeze zips back into view, twice as fast, zips b even faster, out of sight.  Pause. Off screen we hear a cacophony of trash cans and other hi off-screen crash noises.  The empty trapeze swings back i to a stop above the motionless Texan, holding the plates. The violin section of the orchestra stands and executes a stringed tremolo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wally-as-Horton and each of the other Gangsters, wearing mitten pot-holders, holds the pot that contains each of t specialities over the large baking tin.  Lorraine stands a small container of spice. JIMMIE UNDERWOOD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give the word, Horton; all our specialities  are ready. WALLY-AS-HORTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boys, I have a feeling what we're doing in  this kitchen tonight could change the course  of cooking history. BLACK GANGSTER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The aromas themselves are already intermingling  in a way that makes me dizzy with excitement. WALLY-AS-HORTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On three.  One ... two ... three ... They all pour their specialties into the baking tin, a bu cauldron of hot food. WALLY-AS-HORTON (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go, Lorraine Lorraine dumps the spice into the mix.  The mix appears t combustible; a cloud of smoke appears and we hear a sound continuous surf, punctuated by small popping noises.  The the smoke and see that the tin is packed with small, attr green pies.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Creeping down a hallway, toward Ike and Mike, stationed o side of the door to the Rocking Horse room.  As we approa the SOUND of chalk racing over blackboard. Carrying a healthy rum toddy, his fourth, Tidman, in nigh flannel nightshirt and slippers nods to Ike and Mike.  Mi open the door and we catch a glimpse of the Professor-as- scribbling away at a massive blackboard. THE PROFESSOR-AS-NEWT (to himself, as he writes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One ... clean ... pig. TIDMAN (tipsy, nearly won over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No lack of energy, our Newt. Mike closes the door.  TIDMAN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

THE McNABB HOUSE - NIGHT Bob McNabb, lurches up near the curb in the Company "A" l to stop, which he's able to do only long enough to make a towards his house's window before he's off again like a b flames shooting from the tailpipe.  Moments later "Sherlo follows in his patrol car and close behind him are a coup jeeps.  Sammy "the Stomp"-as-Alice dabs at his eyes with a handke slowly closes the curtains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: Has anyone seen the Professor? All eyes turn to the one-way glass: Newt-as-the-Professor longer in the room.  The cover of an air duct had been pr MEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tidman!! TIDMAN (weaving slightly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Standing by, Master Newt. THE-PROFESSOR-AS-NEWT (frantically writing on a pad)

dialogues.text: Very good, Sir.

The Officers all look at each other and smoke their cigar The Heinz Vice President we saw earlier comes out of the office, accompanied by a MALE CHINESE ASSISTANT, doing ca HEINZ VICE PRESIDENT

dialogues.text: Mind if I ask him a few questions? HEINZ VICE PRESIDENT

dialogues.text: Go right ahead. GENERAL CONRAD (smiles at the Chinese man)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flank Loberlts. GENERAL CONRAD (to Mofler)

dialogues.text: What'd he say? COLONEL MOFLER

dialogues.text: He said his name was Frank Roberts. GENERAL CONRAD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Frank, where you from? CHINESE MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rubbock ... wellr, neal Rubbock, 'bout twelvre mires as the clow fries. GENERAL CONRAD (eyes narrowing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you're a citizen of these here  United States of America? CHINESE MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boln and bled. General Conrad bites through his cigar.  We hear a slurpi The Chinese Receptionist is back at her desk, eating a bi chili.

dialogues.text: A sign reads:

dialogues.text: A number of kids are bouncing around on pogo sticks.  Gor showing a couple of them how to work their pogo sticks, w suddenly pushed down from behind. VICTOR EICHORN

dialogues.text: What are you doing, pogo-wimp? VICTOR EICHORN, the class bully, stands over Gordie and g pogo stick, flanked by two of his little HENCHMEN.  Other to gather around, heads bobbing.  Gordie stands back up. GORDIE

dialogues.text: I like to pogo.  Pogoing is cool. VICTOR EICHORN

dialogues.text: You're stupid.  Where'd you get this  stupid thing? GORDIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dad got it for me. VICTOR EICHORN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Dad's the biggest wimp who ever lived,  everyone knows that. GORDIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a lie -- give it back. VICTOR EICHORN

dialogues.text: Why don't you make me, pogo-wimp? GORDIE

dialogues.text: I'm warning you; I know hand-to-hand. Victor and the Henchman chortle menacingly.  One of the H kneels behind Gordie, the other Henchman steps forward to Gordie backwards.  Gordie sidesteps the push and tosses o over the other. VICTOR EICHORN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah? Victor steps forward and tries to punch Gordie; Gordie ex flips him onto his back in the sandbox.  The other kids c OTHER KIDS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah! A thin, nasty teacher, MISS HENKE, appears out of nowhere Gordie by the ear, twisting it viciously. MISS HENKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It looks like I'm going to have to make an example of you, Gordon. GORDIE

dialogues.text: He started it -- MISS HENKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't start with your crying and whimpering,  an ugly trait you inherited from your father. (dragging him towards the school)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe we can beat it out of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the whole fifth grade class seated, facing the fro Gordie is leaning over Miss Henke's desk, while she wield rulers taped together on him.  WHAP!  Gordie stoically be punishment.  WHAP!  Victor and his Henchman smile sadisti GORDIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told the truth.  This is unfair. MISS HENKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Life ... is unfair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GORDIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.  You tell him to come see me.  I  can use this on even bigger babies.  And  I've got a hankie for when big babies cry.

The noise from the s rink is nearly deafening.  General Conrad notices that sm of sawdust are being thrown up from the hardwood rink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gordie, you can take your seat with the rest of the kids. Gordie does.  Horton-as-Wally takes out a switchblade and open.  Miss Henke gasps.  The class is petrified.  Horton picks up the two taped rulers from the desk and breaks th HORTON-AS-WALLY (CONT'D) (to the kids)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There'll be no more beatings in this classroom. Horton-as-Wally takes a big grapefruit out of the paper b on the desk and cuts it in half with the switchblade.  he half the grapefruit and moves to Miss Henke. HORTON-AS-WALLY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My boy doesn't lie, sourpuss. He grinds the grapefruit into her face, using it as a jui tosses the rind across the room into a trashcan like Magi Horton-as-Wally turns to face the class. HORTON-AS-WALLY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At this moment, I consider myself the  luckiest man on earth.  I have a wonderful son, who doesn't lie, and he's made me  very proud. Gordie runs up and embraces Horton-as-Wally with all his VICTOR EICHORN (snidely)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'm gonna puke. Horton-as-Wally turns to Victor. HORTON-AS-WALLY

dialogues.text: Victor, come up here. Frightened, Victor stands and moves to them. VICTOR EICHORN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not the boss a' me. HORTON-AS-WALLY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Calm down, son. (a hand on Victor's shoulder)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor, I know what a hard life you've  lived, what with your folks divorce and  your father's alcoholism.  It wasn't so  long ago that I didn't know the meaning  of a family either.  Victor, I know about  the loneliness, lying awake at night, feeling  like no one in the world cares for you.  I  know what this can do to you; the rage and  frustration.  And I just want you to understand  you've got a friend here and his name is Wally  Newton.  You're welcome at our house, Gordie's  and mine and Polly's, anytime, day or night, for  good food or hand-to-hand lessons and for just  going out to the range with an Uzi or a thirty- ought-six. (Victor's dissolved in helpless tears)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you characters shake hands and call  it square. Gordie extends a hand.  Victor shakes it.  The class chee applauds.  Victor's Henchmen are fighting back their own

A steady steam of Delivery men dolly i deposit their loads under the supervision of a tipsy Tidm and Mike are lifting heavy objects and other members of t Staff are joyfully engaged in various support activities. sits in his wheelchair near the scaffolding, beaming up a Professor-as-Newt. GRANDPA (happily, to anyone who'll listen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not Newt. THE PROFESSOR-AS-NEWT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bring up my uranium rods! Ike and Mike do just that.  Tidman turns to RAYBURN, the Manor Staff Accountant, who's inventorying the incoming s TIDMAN

dialogues.text: Make a note, Rayburn; triple this year's  donation to Soothing Breezes Sanitarium. RAYBURN

dialogues.text: The lad has improved, taken, many, so much more, steps, that I, hard to  find the, but then, words are -- TIDMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Rayburn. THE PROFESSOR-AS-NEWT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I wrong?  I feel as though I've  asked for the plutonium three or  four times already -- TIDMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just coming off the truck, Master Newt. Chef Pierre wheels in a large silver serving trolley. CHEF PIERRE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My treat: jiffy baked Alaska for  everyone!

dialogues.text: The computers are whirring at top speed.  Three sensing d pointed through the mirror at Newt-as-the-Professor, who' chalk on the blackboard in a rhythmic pattern.  The Scien gathered around, Mel, Bert and Sammy "the Stomp"-as-Alice background. SCIENTIST #1

dialogues.text: We're very close now. Scientist #2 picks up a red phone.  SCIENTIST #2

dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, the Eagle has  landed. The room is hushed; more clicks from the computer. SCIENTIST #1 (CONT'D)

dialogues.text: Coming up now ... coming up now ... An IMAGE comes into focus on the big monitor; a large pig it a list of ingredients.  Stunned silence. BERT (aside, to Mel)

dialogues.text: Kind'a looks like a pig)

dialogues.text: Sir, unless I miss my guess there's enough  arbitrary nucleic permutations on the  cobalt theme inside that porker to turn  this world into a corn flake. MR. BIGGS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is worth a fortune but Lord it's  dangerous.  Thank God we got it before  those animal crackers at Company "A".  Start  building immediately.  Now it's more  important than ever we pop the weasel  and drain the tub of Professor Hugo Zinzermacher. (looking at the monitor again)

dialogues.text: Damned if that thing doesn't look like a pig.

dialogues.text: Temporary Army Command Headquarters, set up just outside Newtonville city limits, near the Newtonville sign.  Colo holds a field phone to General Conrad's ear, as the Gener by. GENERAL CONRAD

dialogues.text: No, no, no, nothing's "up" ... the boys  and I found a great little trout stream  out here in Kansas... we're frying up some  rainbows right now, couple a' beers, we'll  be back inside the Beltway before you know  it ... yes I was in Bethesda -- no, nothing  serious, slipped on a rock going for a carp  in the Potomac -- no, I'm fine now, never  better ... thanks very much for calling, you  have a nice day, too, Mr. President. Mofler hangs up the phone. GENERAL CONRAD (CONT'D)

dialogues.text: He was supposed to be out clearing  brush today, Mofler, what the hell kind of intelligence are you giving  me?  We got the feed off that uplink  back to Section Six? COLONEL MOFLER (reading from a file)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Conclusions: the emission had caused  unusual behavior and activity --" GENERAL CONRAD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could'a told you that, Mofler. COLONEL MOFLER (nods, keeps reading)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "-- which does not at this time appear to be life-threatening, but considering  the nature of the deep space random collection samplings, an accurate  projection of long-range consequences  is not possible at this time." GENERAL CONRAD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Recommendations for response? COLONEL MOFLER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three options, Sir ... (reads again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Option #1: do nothing, return to  Washington, deny everything.  Option #2: reduce Newtonville to a smoking pile  of ash, litter the area with sheep with their eyes sewn shut and blame  it on UFO's." (closes the file) GENERAL CONRAD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm leaning towards two.  What's number  three? COLONEL MOFLER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Option #3 is a second emission. GENERAL CONRAD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So.  It's time to fish or cut bait. (pause, jaw set)

dialogues.text: Alright, boys ... we'll pee again.

dialogues.text: The "pig" is completely finished.  Tidman and the Staff s and gaze at it in wondrous admiration.  High up on the sc Ike and Mike help the Professor-as-Newt pour a smoking li funnel on the end of the coiled copper "tail".  Down on t Grandad wheels himself away from the staff, towards a sma button on the "pig's" underbelly. THE PROFESSOR-AS-NEWT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Move away, move away now -- Tidman,  if Grandad were to touch that button,  that would be very bad. The Professor-as-Newt comes down the scaffolding, as Tidm whole Staff cautiously move towards Grandad, who holds hi next to the button. TIDMAN AND STAFF (variously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grandad, don't touch the button ... that's a no-no ... bad to push the  button, Grandad, mustn't push the button ... Grandad pushes the button.  We hear a click, then a roar blast furnace inside the "pig".  A panel slides open and appears, counting down from:  10:00:00. THE PROFESSOR-AS-NEWT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so sorry he did that.  That's very bad. TIDMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surely you can turn whatever it is  off, Master Newt. THE PROFESSOR-AS-NEWT (flicks Tidman on shoulder)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no, the plutonium is lit now.  Once  you light the plutonium, pffft. TIDMAN (quietly and completely insane)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah.  So it is a bomb ... THE PROFESSOR-AS-NEWT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A real dandy. TIDMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how big is your bomb, Master Newt? THE PROFESSOR-AS-NEWT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, very big. Some members of the House Staff faint dead away. TIDMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see.  And you're absolutely certain there's  nothing we can do, really? THE PROFESSOR-AS-NEWT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish. TIDMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wouldn't kid us about something like this, would you, Master Newt? THE PROFESSOR-AS-NEWT (shaking his head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once you light that plutonium ... TIDMAN

dialogues.text: Just about enough for one more good  cup of coffee. Tidman walks to the desert trolley and pours a cup. TIDMAN (stiff upper lip)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cream and sugar, Master Newt? THE PROFESSOR-AS-NEWT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, thank you.

dialogues.text: I said pee immediately!  -- I don't  give a damn about procedures, let's  hose this deck down quick!

The other panel opens, a countdown begins: As the countdown proceeds we notice a large yellow mass l behind the satellite.  We notice a number of "CHEESE IS M MILK" wrappers melded into the mass.  It silently sails p satellite.

dialogues.text: A long line of hungry, head-bobbing Newtonvillonians are little green pies to go, dispensed by Lorraine and the Ga all in Chef's hats, from Vinnie's new "take-out window". Horton and Jimmie Underwood are putting up a sign above t that reads:

dialogues.speaker: TRY OUT RED WINE AND GREEN PIE SPECIAL
